#RankedChoiceVoting is the fastest growing reform in America because it gives people more choices, increases political competition, eliminates costly runoffs, and rewards candidates who appeal to the broadest swath of voters.

Instead of voting for a single candidate, #RCV lets you rank candidates in order of preference. If no candidate wins a majority outright, the last-place candidate is eliminated and you take their voters' next choice into account. Learn more about it here: https://www.fairvote.org/rcv#where_is_ranked_choice_voting_used

Midnight is the darkest point of every day, but what comes after is filled with promise.

Our democracy is far more fragile than we knew, and we are not out of the woods. Nevertheless, we have the capacity to overcome our present circumstances, and it was even more important for me to write about that too.

As I rushed below the Capitol, the fear began to subside and a cold anger took its place. This brazen attack on the citadel of our democracy could have been avoided, if just a few Senators had the courage to convict the President in an impeachment trial I led only months earlier.
Even Republican colleagues urged me to get out, to not let them see me, as my life was in danger. When I finally did get out, it was only moments later that Ashli Babbit was shot.

We need sanity to prevail in DC and for the two parties to work together to prevent default. 

The full faith and credit of our nation should never be in question.  ///

AND it‚Äôs despite the fact that Congressional Republicans and the last Administration racked up nearly $8 trillion in debt ‚Äì nearly 1/4 of our nation‚Äôs total debt ‚Äì in part to give the very wealthiest Americans a tax giveaway. I don‚Äôt say that in a partisan way - it‚Äôs just a fact.

Senate Republicans have been threatening to filibuster ANY legislation to address the debt limit. 

That‚Äôs despite the fact that Mitch McConnell has previously said ‚ÄúAmerica must never default‚Äù and that failing to address it would be ‚Äúplaying Russian roulette with our economy.‚Äù

That‚Äôs why I supported legislation that passed the House on September 29 to suspend the debt limit.

Unfortunately, there are some shenanigans occurring in the U.S. Senate that has made the road forward a bit bumpy.

((side note: this clip from The West Wing explains it in a far more entertaining way than I could ever))
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v5igKuNF1rI

In essence, failing to address the debt ceiling is a bit like choosing not to pay the minimum balance on your credit card. 

You can make that choice ‚Äì but it DEFINITELY has bad consequences for your finances down the road.

Recent analyses suggest that failure to act could cost America‚Äôs economy as much as 6‚É£ MILLION jobs. 

In addition, it would also likely delay payments for critical programs like Social Security, Medicare, and veterans‚Äô benefits.

Again ‚Äì why does that matter? 

Well, nearly every economist across the political spectrum has acknowledged this would damage the economy and make it more expensive for folks to borrow money to buy a car or home, or to start or grow a small business.

So why is this in the press right now? Well, it‚Äôs expected that the Treasury Department will run out of those options to address the debt ceiling by October 18. At that point, if Congress fails to take action, the government would default.
Raising or suspending the debt limit does NOT authorize new spending but allows the government to pay for ‚û°Ô∏èpreviously made commitments‚¨ÖÔ∏è

Our nation is a bit unique in that it puts in law how much debt can be incurred by the U.S. Treasury. 

Why does that matter? Well, it limits the amount the federal government can pay on debt the government has ALREADY borrowed.

There‚Äôs a fair amount of press attention about the debt ceiling (also known as the debt limit) - especially coming out of DC and the national news media.

What is it? Why does it matter to folks in our region? Is this actually a big deal (hint: yes)?

Let's dig in üßµ‚¨áÔ∏è
